English.statement: You can’t get pregnant the first time you have sex.
English.explanation: Myth! You can get pregnant anytime you have unprotected sex — even the first time.

English.statement: Condoms protect against both pregnancy and STIs.
English.explanation: Fact! When used correctly, condoms reduce the risk of both pregnancy and many STIs.

English.statement: Using two condoms gives double protection.
English.explanation: Myth! Using two condoms can cause friction between them and increase the chance of breakage.

English.statement: HIV can be transmitted through mosquito bites.
English.explanation: Myth! HIV cannot be spread by mosquitoes — it only spreads through certain body fluids.

English.statement: Taking a shower or urinating after sex can prevent pregnancy.
English.explanation: Myth! Neither bathing nor urinating after sex can prevent pregnancy.

English.statement: Only promiscuous people get sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
English.explanation: Myth! Anyone who is sexually active can get an STI, regardless of the number of partners.

English.statement: Birth control pills can make a woman infertile.
English.explanation: Myth! Birth control pills are reversible and do not cause permanent infertility.

English.statement: STIs always show symptoms.
English.explanation: Myth! Many STIs have no symptoms. That’s why regular testing is important.

English.statement: You can’t get an STI if you and your partner are both virgins.
English.explanation: Fact! If neither partner has engaged in any sexual activity, the risk of STIs is extremely low.

English.statement: Withdrawal (pull-out method) is a reliable form of contraception.
English.explanation: Myth! Withdrawal is very risky and not reliable, as pre-ejaculate can contain sperm.

English.statement: HPV (Human Papillomavirus) can lead to cervical cancer.
English.explanation: Fact! Certain types of HPV can cause cervical cancer, which is why vaccination is important.

English.statement: You don’t need to use protection during oral sex.
English.explanation: Myth! STIs can still be transmitted through oral sex — protection is advised.

English.statement: Men cannot get the HPV virus.
English.explanation: Myth! Men can also be infected with HPV and may develop related health issues.

English.statement: Emergency contraception can only be used the day after sex.
English.explanation: Myth! Emergency contraception can be effective for up to 3–5 days after unprotected sex.

English.statement: A girl cannot get pregnant during her period.
English.explanation: Myth! It’s rare, but possible to get pregnant during menstruation due to sperm living several days in the body.

English.statement: You can tell if someone has an STI just by looking at them.
English.explanation: Myth! Most STIs don’t show visible symptoms, so testing is the only way to know.

English.statement: Condoms can expire and should be discarded after the expiration date.
English.explanation: Fact! Using an expired condom risks it breaking — always check the date.

English.statement: Douching after sex helps prevent STIs.
English.explanation: Myth! Douching doesn’t protect against STIs and can upset vaginal balance.

English.statement: The morning-after pill is the same as abortion.
English.explanation: Myth! Emergency contraception prevents pregnancy; it doesn't terminate it.

English.statement: HIV can be transmitted through sharing a toothbrush or a towel.
English.explanation: Myth! HIV isn’t spread by casual contact—only via blood, semen, vaginal fluids, or breast milk.

English.statement: Using birth control pills protects against STIs.
English.explanation: Myth! Pills prevent pregnancy only — they don’t protect against STIs.

English.statement: You can't get an STI from a toilet seat.
English.explanation: Fact! STIs don’t live long on surfaces and are not transmitted through toilet seats.

English.statement: Taking birth control causes weight gain in everyone.
English.explanation: Myth! Not everyone gains weight — effects vary depending on the individual and the type of birth control.

English.statement: Only people who sleep around need STI tests.
English.explanation: Myth! Anyone who is sexually active should consider regular STI testing, regardless of their number of partners.

English.statement: STIs can affect your fertility.
English.explanation: Fact! Untreated STIs like chlamydia and gonorrhea can cause fertility problems.

English.statement: You can’t get HIV if both partners are healthy-looking.
English.explanation: Myth! People with HIV often show no symptoms — only testing can confirm HIV status.

English.statement: Only women need to worry about contraception.
English.explanation: Myth! Preventing pregnancy and STIs is a shared responsibility between partners.

English.statement: STIs are less dangerous for men than women.
English.explanation: Myth! STIs can cause serious health issues in all genders if left untreated.

English.statement: You can get pregnant even if it's your first time having sex.
English.explanation: Fact! Pregnancy can happen any time there's unprotected sex — even the first time.

English.statement: You should see a doctor immediately if you think you have an STI.
English.explanation: Fact! Early treatment can prevent complications and stop spread to others.

English.statement: Talking about sex with a partner ruins the mood.
English.explanation: Myth! Open communication builds trust, safety, and a better sexual experience.

English.statement: You can get an STI the first time you have sex.
English.explanation: Fact! STIs can be passed during any unprotected sexual contact, even the first time.

English.statement: You can’t get pregnant if it’s your first time having sex.
English.explanation: Myth! Pregnancy can happen anytime there's unprotected sex — even the first time.

English.statement: You can tell if someone has an STI just by looking at them.
English.explanation: Myth! Many STIs don’t show visible signs. Only testing can confirm if someone has an STI.

English.statement: HIV can be spread through blood.
English.explanation: Fact! HIV can be spread through blood, as well as semen, vaginal fluids, and breast milk.

English.statement: You can’t get HIV from hugging, sharing food, or using the same toilet.
English.explanation: Fact! HIV is not spread through casual contact like hugging or sharing a toilet.

English.statement: Girls can’t get pregnant during their period.
English.explanation: Myth! It’s rare, but possible — sperm can live in the body for several days.

English.statement: Only girls need to learn about STIs and pregnancy.
English.explanation: Myth! Everyone should understand how STIs and pregnancy happen and how to prevent them.

English.statement: You can get an STI from oral sex.
English.explanation: Fact! STIs can be passed through all types of unprotected sexual contact.

English.statement: You can’t get pregnant from kissing or holding hands.
English.explanation: Fact! Pregnancy can only happen from vaginal sex, not from kissing or touching.

English.statement: STIs only happen to people who don’t shower or stay clean.
English.explanation: Myth! STIs are passed through sexual contact — not because someone is 'dirty'.

English.statement: Condoms help protect against both pregnancy and STIs.
English.explanation: Fact! When used correctly, condoms help prevent both pregnancy and many STIs.

English.statement: Only adults can get STIs.
English.explanation: Myth! Anyone who is sexually active, including teens, can get an STI.

English.statement: You can't get an STI if both partners are virgins.
English.explanation: Fact! If neither person has had any sexual contact, the risk of STI is very low.

English.statement: There are vaccines to prevent some STIs.
English.explanation: Fact! The HPV vaccine, for example, can help protect against certain cancers caused by HPV.

English.statement: You can get HIV from a mosquito bite.
English.explanation: Myth! HIV cannot be spread by mosquitoes — only through specific body fluids.

English.statement: STIs always have symptoms like itching or discharge.
English.explanation: Myth! Many STIs have no symptoms — which is why testing is important.

English.statement: Using two condoms at once gives better protection.
English.explanation: Myth! Using two condoms can cause friction and make them more likely to break.

English.statement: People with HIV can live long, healthy lives with treatment.
English.explanation: Fact! HIV is treatable, and with medicine, many people live full lives.

English.statement: Only people with lots of partners get STIs.
English.explanation: Myth! Anyone who is sexually active can get an STI, even with one partner.

English.statement: Washing after sex prevents pregnancy.
English.explanation: Myth! Washing doesn’t prevent pregnancy or STIs — only protection does.

English.statement: STIs can be cured with antibiotics.
English.explanation: Fact! Many STIs like chlamydia or gonorrhea can be cured — but others like HIV cannot.

English.statement: Toilet seats can spread STIs.
English.explanation: Myth! STIs don’t live long on surfaces and aren’t spread by toilet seats.

English.statement: It’s important to talk to a trusted adult if you’re confused about sex, STIs, or pregnancy.
English.explanation: Fact! Trusted adults can give you correct, helpful information.

English.statement: You can get pregnant if sperm gets near the vagina, even without full sex.
English.explanation: Fact! Pregnancy is possible if sperm enters the vagina, even without full intercourse.

English.statement: Birth control pills protect against STIs.
English.explanation: Myth! Birth control pills prevent pregnancy but not STIs.

English.statement: People with STIs always know they have one.
English.explanation: Myth! Many people don’t have symptoms and may not know unless they get tested.

English.statement: The only 100% way to avoid STIs and pregnancy is not having sex.
English.explanation: Fact! Abstinence is the only guaranteed way to avoid pregnancy and STIs.

English.statement: You can get STIs from sharing drinks.
English.explanation: Myth! STIs don’t spread through cups or drinks — only through sexual contact or body fluids.

English.statement: Only adults should get tested for STIs.
English.explanation: Myth! Anyone who is sexually active, no matter their age, should consider STI testing.

English.statement: STIs can make it harder to have children later.
English.explanation: Fact! Untreated STIs can cause fertility problems later in life.

English.statement: You can still get pregnant even if your partner pulls out before ejaculation.
English.explanation: Myth! Pre-ejaculate can contain sperm, so the pull-out method is not reliable.

English.statement: Birth control methods like the pill do not protect against STIs.
English.explanation: Fact! Most hormonal birth control methods prevent pregnancy, not STIs. Use condoms for STI protection.

English.statement: You can’t get an STI from someone who looks healthy.
English.explanation: Myth! Many people with STIs have no symptoms at all — testing is the only way to know.

English.statement: HPV is the most common STI and can affect all genders.
English.explanation: Fact! HPV is very common, and both men and women can carry and transmit it.

English.statement: Using condoms correctly every time you have sex greatly lowers your risk of STIs and pregnancy.
English.explanation: Fact! Condoms are highly effective when used consistently and correctly.

English.statement: Emergency contraception causes an abortion.
English.explanation: Myth! Emergency contraception prevents pregnancy — it does not end one.

English.statement: Most STIs are curable with treatment.
English.explanation: Fact! Many STIs (like chlamydia and gonorrhea) can be cured, while others (like herpes or HIV) are manageable.

English.statement: You don’t need to get tested for STIs if you're in a long-term relationship.
English.explanation: Myth! It’s still important to test, especially if neither partner was tested before the relationship began.

English.statement: You can get an STI from oral and anal sex.
English.explanation: Fact! STIs can be transmitted through all forms of sexual contact without protection.

English.statement: Men can’t carry or transmit HPV.
English.explanation: Myth! Men can carry and transmit HPV, even without symptoms.

English.statement: Using lube with condoms can help prevent breakage.
English.explanation: Fact! Water- or silicone-based lube can reduce friction and help keep condoms from breaking.

English.statement: Doubling up on condoms gives you more protection.
English.explanation: Myth! Using two condoms at once increases friction and the chance of breakage.

English.statement: HIV is no longer a life-threatening condition with proper treatment.
English.explanation: Fact! Antiretroviral therapy allows people with HIV to live long, healthy lives.

English.statement: Birth control can cause infertility.
English.explanation: Myth! Most birth control methods are reversible and do not cause long-term fertility issues.

English.statement: You can get pregnant even if you’ve never missed a birth control pill.
English.explanation: Fact! No method is 100% effective — though the pill is over 90% effective with perfect use.

English.statement: Douching after sex helps prevent pregnancy or STIs.
English.explanation: Myth! Douching does not prevent pregnancy or infections and can disrupt vaginal health.

English.statement: People who are in monogamous relationships don’t need STI tests.
English.explanation: Myth! Even in monogamous relationships, STI testing is recommended unless both partners have been tested before becoming exclusive.

English.statement: Pregnancy is possible even with 'just one time' unprotected sex.
English.explanation: Fact! It only takes one time for pregnancy to occur if no protection is used.

English.statement: You can't get STIs if you’re using hormonal birth control.
English.explanation: Myth! Hormonal methods protect against pregnancy, not against STIs.

English.statement: A person with an STI can still be a good partner.
English.explanation: Fact! With honesty, treatment, and protection, healthy relationships are possible.

English.statement: It’s okay to delay testing for STIs if you don’t have symptoms.
English.explanation: Myth! Many STIs have no symptoms — regular testing is important if you're sexually active.

English.statement: Using protection during sex is a shared responsibility.
English.explanation: Fact! Preventing pregnancy and STIs involves communication and mutual care.

English.statement: You should get tested after each new sexual partner.
English.explanation: Fact! Testing helps protect you and your partner’s health.

English.statement: The withdrawal method is highly effective at preventing pregnancy.
English.explanation: Myth! It's much less effective than condoms or hormonal methods.

English.statement: You can’t get pregnant if you're breastfeeding.
English.explanation: Myth! Breastfeeding may reduce fertility but doesn’t guarantee you won’t get pregnant.

English.statement: It's safe to rely only on emergency contraception regularly.
English.explanation: Myth! Emergency contraception is for occasional use and is not as effective as regular birth control.

English.statement: Using condoms during oral sex lowers the risk of STI transmission.
English.explanation: Fact! Condoms and dental dams help protect during oral sex too.

English.statement: HPV can lead to cancer in both men and women.
English.explanation: Fact! HPV can lead to cancers such as cervical, throat, and anal cancer.

English.statement: If your STI test comes back negative, you never need to test again.
English.explanation: Myth! Regular testing is important if you're sexually active, especially with new or multiple partners.

English.statement: STIs can affect your ability to have children in the future.
English.explanation: Fact! Untreated STIs can lead to infertility in both men and women.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le loyun ni igba akoko ti o ba ni ibalopọ.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! O le loyun nigbakugba ti o ba ni ibalopọ lai lo idaabobo — paapaa ni igba akọkọ.

Yoruba.statement: Kondomu daabobo mejeeji lodi si oyun ati awọn arun ibalopọ.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Nigbati a ba lo kondomu tọna, o dinku ewu oyun ati ọpọlọpọ STIs.

Yoruba.statement: Lilo kondomu meji ni igba kan maa n pese aabo meji.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Lilo kondomu meji le fa fifọ laarin wọn, eyi ti o le fa ki wọn bàjẹ́.

Yoruba.statement: HIV le tan kaakiri nipasẹ kokoro jije.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! HIV ko le tan nipasẹ kokoro — o tan nipasẹ awọn omi ara pato nikan.

Yoruba.statement: Wíwẹ̀ tabi mimi lẹ́yìn ibalopọ le dena oyun.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Mimi tabi wíwẹ̀ lẹ́yìn ibalopọ ko le dena oyun.

Yoruba.statement: Àwọn ènìyàn àtẹ̀yìnwá nikan ni a le ní STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ẹnikẹ́ni tí ó bá ń ṣe ibalopọ le ní STI, koda pẹlu alabaṣepọ kan ṣoṣo.

Yoruba.statement: Pilu oyun le fa ki obinrin má le loyun mọ́.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Pilu oyun jẹ́ àfọ̀mọ́ra — ko fa ki obinrin má le loyun mọ́.

Yoruba.statement: STI maa n fihan ami nigbagbogbo.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ STI kìí ní àmi kankan. Ìdánwò deede ló jẹ́ àkọ́kọ́ láti mọ.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le ni STI ti iwọ ati alabaṣepọ rẹ jẹ́ wínrìn.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Bí ẹnikẹ́ni kò bá ti ní irú ibalopọ kankan, ewu STI jẹ́ kékèké gan-an.

Yoruba.statement: Ọna yíyọ lórí (withdrawal) jẹ́ ọna idena oyun tí ó dáa.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ọna yíyọ lewu gan-an — pre-ejaculate le ni sperm.

Yoruba.statement: HPV le fa àkàn ẹ̀dọ-fún-fún (cervical cancer).
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Diẹ ninu HPV le fa àkàn ẹ̀dọ-fún-fún — èyí ni kó ṣe pàtàkì lati gba abẹrẹ ajesara.

Yoruba.statement: O ko nilo idaabobo nigba ti o ba n ṣe ibalopọ ẹnu.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! STIs le tan nipasẹ ibalopọ ẹnu — idaabobo yẹ kí a lo.

Yoruba.statement: Awọn ọkunrin ko le ni HPV.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Awọn ọkunrin le ni HPV àti jiyàn àìlera tó ní ibatan pẹ̀lú rẹ.

Yoruba.statement: Ìtọ́jú pajawiri le ṣiṣẹ́ lọ́jọ́ kejì lẹ́yìn ibalopọ nikan.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ìtọ́jú pajawiri le wúlò títí di ọjọ́ kẹta tàbí karun.

Yoruba.statement: Obinrin ko le loyun nigba ti o ba wa l’akoko (period).
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ó ṣòro, ṣùgbọ́n ó ṣeeṣe — sperm le wà lára obìnrin fún ọ̀pọ̀ ọjọ́.

Yoruba.statement: O le mọ̀ pé ẹnikan ní STI nipa fífi ojú wo wọn.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ STI kò ní àmi tí a lè rí — àyẹ̀wò ni ọ̀nà tó dájú.

Yoruba.statement: Kondomu le pari ọjọ́ rẹ̀ — kí o fi silẹ lẹ́yìn ọjọ́ tó wúlò.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Kondomu tó parí le fọ — ṣáyẹ̀wò ọjọ́ tó lórí rẹ.

Yoruba.statement: Ìwẹ̀wẹ̀ (douching) lẹ́yìn ibalopọ daabobo lodi sí STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ìwẹ̀wẹ̀ ko daabobo STI — ó le dá ààyè ìbálẹ̀ obìnrin lóró.

Yoruba.statement: Pilu pajawiri jẹ́ ìṣẹ̀dá oyún (abortion).
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ẹ̀rọ oyún pajawiri n ṣe idiwọ oyun, kò pa oyún run.

Yoruba.statement: HIV le tan kaakiri nipa pípa brọshu ẹnu pọ tàbí tọọwẹlì.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! HIV ko tan kaakiri nípa fífi ohun wọpọ lo — o tan nípa omi ara kan ṣoṣo.

Yoruba.statement: Lilo pilu oyun daabobo lodi sí STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Pilu oyun n dènà oyun nikan — kò daabobo lodi sí STI.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le ní STI látọ̀run ijoko balùwẹ̀.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! STI ko le yè lórí ojú ilẹ̀ — kò tan kaakiri nípa ijoko balùwẹ̀.

Yoruba.statement: Gbigba pilu oyun maa n fa ki gbogbo obinrin gbàra.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Kò jẹ́ pé gbogbo obinrin ni ipa tó yàtọ̀ — ipa rẹ da lori ara ẹni ati irú pilu.

Yoruba.statement: Kí àwọn tí kò ní alabaṣepọ púpò̀ nikan ló nílò ayẹwo STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ẹnikẹ́ni tí ó bá ń ṣe ibalopọ yẹ kí o ma ṣe ayẹwo STI lọ́pọ̀lọpọ̀.

Yoruba.statement: STI le ni ipa lórí agbára lati loyun.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! STIs tí kò bá gba ìtọ́jú le fa iṣoro loyun.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le ní HIV tí iwọ àti alabaṣepọ rẹ dájú pé ara wọn dáa.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn tí ó ní HIV kò ní àmi — ayẹwo nikan ló lè jẹ́ kedere.

Yoruba.statement: Obinrin nikan ni o yẹ kí o ròyìn oyun.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ìdènà oyun àti STI jẹ́ ojuse pẹ̀lú mejeeji.

Yoruba.statement: STI jẹ́ kékèké jùlọ fún àwọn ọkùnrin.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! STI le fa àìlera tó lewu fún gbogbo ènìyàn tí kò bá gba ìtọ́jú.

Yoruba.statement: O le loyun koda tí o jẹ́ igba akọkọ rẹ.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! O le loyun nigbakugba ti o ba ṣe ibalopọ lai lo idaabobo — paapaa igba akọkọ.

Yoruba.statement: O yẹ kí o ṣàbẹwò dókítà lẹsẹkẹsẹ tí o bá rò pé o ní STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Ìtọ́jú tete le dènà iṣoro àtẹ̀yìnwá àti títan sáwọn míì.

Yoruba.statement: Sísọ̀rọ̀ nípa ibalopọ máa n bà ìmúra jẹ́.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ìbànújẹ̀ sísọ̀tọ̀ n dá ìgbẹ́kẹ̀lé sílẹ̀, ààbò àti ìrírí ibalopọ tó dáa.

Yoruba.statement: O le ní STI koda ní igba akọkọ ti o bá ni ibalopọ.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! STI le tan nigbakugba ti ibalopọ ba waye lai idaabobo, paapaa igba akọkọ.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le loyun tí ó bá jẹ́ igba akọkọ rẹ.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! O le loyun nigbakugba tí ibalopọ ba waye lai idaabobo — paapaa igba akọkọ.

Yoruba.statement: O le mọ̀ pé ẹnikan ní STI nipa fífi ojú wo wọn.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ STI kò ní àmi — ayẹwo nikan ló le jẹ́ gidi.

Yoruba.statement: HIV le tan kaakiri nípa ẹ̀jẹ̀.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! HIV le tan nípa ẹ̀jẹ̀, omi sẹ́mìnì, omi ibálẹ̀ obìnrin àti wara ọmú.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le ní HIV láti fi ara mọ́, jẹun pọ̀ tàbí lo balùwẹ̀ kan naa.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! HIV kìí tan kaakiri nípa fífi ara mọ́ tàbí lo ohun kan pọ̀ — o tan nípa omi ara kan ṣoṣo.

Yoruba.statement: Awon obinrin ko le loyun nigba akoko won.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ó ṣòro, ṣùgbọ́n ó ṣeeṣe — sperm le wà lára obìnrin fún ọjọ́ mélòó kan.

Yoruba.statement: Awon obinrin nikan ni o nilo lati ko eko nipa STI ati oyun.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Gbogbo ènìyàn yẹ kí wọn mọ bí oyun ati STI ṣe n ṣẹlẹ̀ àti bí a ṣe le dá wọn dúró.

Yoruba.statement: O le ní STI lati inu ibalopọ ẹnu.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! STIs le tan ní gbogbo irú ibalopọ tí kò bá ní idaabobo.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le loyun nipa fífi ẹnu kọ́ tàbí fi ọwọ́ kan.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Oyun ṣẹlẹ̀ nípa ibalopọ obìnrin ati ọkùnrin — kìí ṣẹlẹ̀ nipa fífi ọwọ́ tàbí ẹnu.

Yoruba.statement: STI ṣẹlẹ̀ sí ẹni tí kò ba wẹ tàbí mọ́ ara mọ́.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! STI tan kaakiri nípa ibalopọ — kìí jẹ́ pé ẹni naa kò mọ́ ara rẹ mọ́.

Yoruba.statement: Kondomu le daabobo lodi si oyun ati STIs.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Nígbà tí a bá lo kondomu tọna, o ṣe iranlọwọ lati dènà oyun ati ọpọlọpọ STIs.

Yoruba.statement: Àwọn agbalagba nikan ló le ní STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ẹnikẹ́ni tí ó bá ní ibalopọ le ní STI, paapáà jùlọ àwọn ọdọ.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le ní STI ti ẹyọ méjèèjì jẹ́ wínrìn.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Bí ẹnikẹ́ni kò bá ti ní ibalopọ kankan, ewu STI kere pupọ.

Yoruba.statement: A wa ajesara tó le dènà diẹ ninu STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Ajesara HPV le daabobo lodi sí diẹ ninu àkàn tó jẹ́ abajade HPV.

Yoruba.statement: O le ní HIV nipasẹ kokoro jije.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! HIV ko tan kaakiri nipasẹ kokoro jije — o tan nipa omi ara kan ṣoṣo.

Yoruba.statement: STIs maa n fihan àmi bí itching tàbí omi tí ń jáde.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ STI kìí ní àmi — Ìdánwò ni ọ̀nà tó dájú.

Yoruba.statement: Lilo kondomu méjì lẹ́kan ṣoṣo n fun ni aabo tó pọ̀.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Lilo kondomu méjì le fa ki wọn fọ́ nitori íja laarin wọn.

Yoruba.statement: Àwọn ènìyàn tó ní HIV le wà láradá pẹ̀lú ìtọ́jú.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Pẹ̀lú ìtọ́jú to peye, wọ́n le wà láyọ̀ pẹ̀lú ilera tó dáa.

Yoruba.statement: Àwọn tí ó ní alabaṣepọ púpọ̀ nikan ló ní STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ẹnikẹ́ni tí ó bá ní ibalopọ le ní STI, paapáà pẹ̀lú alabaṣepọ kan ṣoṣo.

Yoruba.statement: Wíwẹ̀ lẹ́yìn ibalopọ le dènà oyun.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Wíwẹ̀ kìí ṣe idena oyun tàbí STI — idaabobo ló dájú.

Yoruba.statement: STIs le jẹ̀wọ̀ kí a fi antibiotics to tọ́jú wọn.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Diẹ ninu STIs bíi chlamydia àti gonorrhea le jẹ̀wọ̀ pẹ̀lú antibiotics.

Yoruba.statement: A le ní STI láti ijoko balùwẹ̀.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! STIs kìí yè lórí ojú ilẹ̀ — wọn kò tan kaakiri nípa ijoko balùwẹ̀.

Yoruba.statement: Ó ṣe pàtàkì láti bá agà tí a gbẹ́kẹ̀ lé sọrọ nípa ibalopọ, STIs tàbí oyun.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Agà tí o gbẹ́kẹ̀ lé le fun ọ ní ìmọ̀ tó tọ́.

Yoruba.statement: O le loyun koda tí ọkùnrin naa kò ba fi gbogbo sperm rẹ̀ sílẹ̀.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Pre-ejaculate le ni sperm — o ṣeeṣe lati loyun.

Yoruba.statement: Pilu oyun le daabobo lodi sí STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Pilu oyun daabobo lodi sí oyun nikan — ko ṣiṣẹ́ lodi sí STIs.

Yoruba.statement: Ẹnikẹ́ni tí ó ní STI maa n mọ̀ pé ó ní i.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn kìí mọ pé wọ́n ní STI ayafi tí wọ́n bá ṣe ayẹwo.

Yoruba.statement: Ọna kan ṣoṣo tó dájú láti dènà STI àti oyun ni kìí ṣe ibalopọ.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Kí o má ṣe ibalopọ rárá ni ọna kan ṣoṣo tí ko ní ewu.

Yoruba.statement: O le ní STI nipa pípa kọ̀pà pọ̀.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! STIs kìí tan kaakiri nípa pípa kọ̀pà pọ̀ — wọn tan nipasẹ ibalopọ.

Yoruba.statement: Àwọn agbalagba nikan ni o yẹ kí wọn ṣe ayẹwo STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ẹnikẹ́ni tí ó bá ní ibalopọ yẹ kí ó ṣe ayẹwo, kí ó tó pé ọjọ-ori agbalagba.

Yoruba.statement: STIs le ba ìṣẹ́ oyún lóró ní ọjọ iwájú.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! STIs tí kò bá gba ìtọ́jú le fa àìlera oyún ní ọjọ iwájú.

Yoruba.statement: O le loyun koda tí alabaṣepọ rẹ ba yọ́ ṣáájú ki o to yọ̀.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Pre-ejaculate le ni sperm, ọna yíyọ̀ kìí jẹ́ ìtójú tó dájú.

Yoruba.statement: Àwọn ọna pilu oyun kò daabobo lodi sí STI.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Pilu oyun daabobo lodi sí oyun nikan — kondomu ni a nilo fún STI.

Yoruba.statement: O ko le ní STI látọ̀run ẹni tó ń dáa.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn tí ó ní STI kìí ní àmi kankan — ayẹwo nikan ló dájú.

Yoruba.statement: HPV jẹ́ STI tó wọpọ̀ jùlọ, ó sì le kan gbogbo akọ àti abo.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! HPV wọpọ gan-an — ó le kan akọ àti abo.

Yoruba.statement: Lilo kondomu tọna gbogbo igba dinku ewu STI ati oyun.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Kondomu jẹ́ gíga munadoko tí a bá lo tọna.

Yoruba.statement: Ìtọ́jú pajawiri jẹ́ àbòyún (abortion).
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ìtọ́jú pajawiri n dènà oyun — kò pa oyun run.

Yoruba.statement: Ọ̀pọ̀ STI le jẹ̀wọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìtọ́jú.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ STI bí chlamydia àti gonorrhea le jẹ̀wọ̀, àwọn mìíràn bí herpes tàbí HIV le jẹ́ àgbéyẹ̀wò.

Yoruba.statement: O ko nilo ayẹwo STI tí o bá wà nínú ibasepọ pípẹ́.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Ayẹwo ṣi jẹ́ pàtàkì, pàápàá tí ẹnikẹ́ni kò bá ti ṣe ayẹwo ṣáájú ibasepọ.

Yoruba.statement: O le ní STI lati ibalopọ ẹnu tàbí ìdí.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! STIs le tan kaakiri ní gbogbo irú ibalopọ tí kò ní idaabobo.

Yoruba.statement: Ìjẹ̀wọ̀ pé ìwọ àti alabaṣepọ rẹ ti ṣe ayẹwo STI ṣáájú ibalopọ le din ewu rẹ kù.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti ayẹwo ṣáájú ibalopọ jẹ́ apá pàtàkì fún aabo ilera ibalopọ.

Yoruba.statement: Kondomu kìí fọ bí o bá lo wọn tọna.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Nígbà tí a bá lo kondomu tọna, ewu fọ wọn kere gan-an.

Yoruba.statement: Ìmúlójú oyún (pregnancy) le ṣẹlẹ̀ ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ lẹ́yìn ibalopọ àkọ́kọ́.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Ẹnikẹ́ni tó ní ibalopọ obìnrin àti ọkùnrin le loyun, koda lẹ́kọ̀ọ́kan ṣoṣo.

Yoruba.statement: Bí obìnrin bá ń mu oyun, kò le ní STI tuntun.
Yoruba.explanation: Ìtàn ni! Oyun kò dá obìnrin dúró láti ní STI — idaabobo ṣi wulo.

Yoruba.statement: Kí ẹni ṣàì ní àìlera, kò túmọ̀ sí pé kò ní HIV.
Yoruba.explanation: Otitọ ni! Ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn tí ó ní HIV kìí ní àmi kankan fún ọdún púpọ̀ — ayẹwo nikan ni ó dájú.

Pidgin.statement: You no fit get belle the first time wey you do sex.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Anytime you do unprotected sex, even if na your first time, you fit still get belle.

Pidgin.statement: Condom dey protect against belle and STIs.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If you use condom well, e go reduce the chance make person get belle or contract STIs.

Pidgin.statement: If you use two condom together, na double protection be that.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Two condom fit rub each other and tear, wey go make e less safe.

Pidgin.statement: Mosquito fit give person HIV.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! HIV no dey spread through mosquito bite. Na through certain body fluid e dey spread.

Pidgin.statement: If you baff or piss after sex, you no go get belle.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! To baff or piss after sex no dey stop belle.

Pidgin.statement: Na only people wey dey sleep around dey get STIs.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Anybody wey dey do sex fit get STI, no matter how many partner dem get.

Pidgin.statement: Birth control pills dey make woman no fit born again.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Pills no dey cause permanent wahala. If person stop am, dem fit still born.

Pidgin.statement: STIs always dey show sign.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Plenty STIs no dey show any sign. Na why testing dey important.

Pidgin.statement: If you and your partner na virgin, you no fit get STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If una never do any sexual thing before, the chance to get STI low well well.

Pidgin.statement: Withdrawal (pull-out method) na sure way to prevent belle.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Pre-cum fit still get sperm. E no sure like condom or other methods.

Pidgin.statement: HPV fit cause cervical cancer.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! Some type of HPV dey cause cervical cancer. Na why HPV vaccine dey important.

Pidgin.statement: You no need use condom for oral sex.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! STI fit still enter through oral sex. Condom or dental dam still dey help.

Pidgin.statement: Men no fit get HPV.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Men fit get HPV and e fit still cause wahala for their body.

Pidgin.statement: Emergency contraception dey work only the next day after sex.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! E fit still work for 3–5 days after the sex, depending on the type.

Pidgin.statement: Girl no fit get belle if she dey her period.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! E rare, but e fit happen because sperm fit survive for days inside body.

Pidgin.statement: You fit know person get STI just by looking them.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Most STIs no dey show for body. Testing na the only sure way.

Pidgin.statement: Expired condom no good to use.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If condom don expire, e fit tear. Always check date before you use am.

Pidgin.statement: To douche after sex go stop STIs.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Douching no dey protect person and fit even disturb the vagina.

Pidgin.statement: Morning-after pill and abortion na the same thing.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Morning-after pill dey stop belle from happen — e no dey end belle wey don start.

Pidgin.statement: If person look healthy, dem no fit get HIV.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Person fit get HIV and still look fine. Only test go show true result.

Pidgin.statement: Pills dey protect against STIs.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Pills dey stop belle but dem no dey protect from STIs.

Pidgin.statement: Toilet seat no fit give person STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! STIs no dey live long for surface like toilet seat. Dem no dey spread like that.

Pidgin.statement: Birth control dey make everybody fat.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! E no happen to everybody — e depend on person and the kind control wey dem use.

Pidgin.statement: Na only people wey sleep around need STI test.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Anybody wey dey do sex suppose dey test, no matter how many partner dem get.

Pidgin.statement: STIs fit affect person fertility.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If person no treat STI like chlamydia or gonorrhea, e fit spoil chance to born later.

Pidgin.statement: If two partners look healthy, dem no fit get HIV.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! HIV no dey always show sign. Test na the only sure way to sabi.

Pidgin.statement: Na only woman suppose worry about pregnancy control.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Na both man and woman get responsibility to stop belle and STI.

Pidgin.statement: STIs no too serious for men reach women.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! STIs fit harm anybody if dem no treat am, whether man or woman.

Pidgin.statement: You fit get belle even if na your first time do sex.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! Any time wey you do unprotected sex, you fit get belle.

Pidgin.statement: If you feel say you get STI, make you go hospital sharp sharp.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! Early treatment dey stop big wahala and make you no pass am give person.

Pidgin.statement: To talk about sex with your partner go spoil the mood.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! To talk well with your partner go make una trust each other and enjoy the sex more.

Pidgin.statement: You fit get STI the first time wey you do sex.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! STI fit enter from the very first time wey person do unprotected sex.

Pidgin.statement: You no fit get belle if na your first time wey you do sex.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Belle fit happen anytime wey you do unprotected sex, even the first time.

Pidgin.statement: You fit know person get STI just by looking them.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Many STIs no dey show for body. Na only test go show.

Pidgin.statement: HIV fit spread through blood.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! HIV dey spread through blood, semen, vaginal fluid and breast milk.

Pidgin.statement: You no fit get HIV from hugging, share food or use same toilet.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! HIV no dey spread through casual contact like that.

Pidgin.statement: Girls no fit get belle during their period.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! E rare but e fit happen because sperm fit still dey body for some days.

Pidgin.statement: Na only girls suppose learn about STI and pregnancy.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Everybody suppose sabi how STI and pregnancy dey happen and how to prevent am.

Pidgin.statement: You fit get STI from oral sex.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! STI fit enter from any kind unprotected sex, even oral.

Pidgin.statement: You no fit get belle from kissing or holding hands.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! Na only sex fit make person get belle — not touching or kissing.

Pidgin.statement: Na dirty people dey get STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! STI dey spread through sex — no be because person no dey clean.

Pidgin.statement: Condom dey help protect from belle and STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If you use condom well, e go protect you from plenty wahala.

Pidgin.statement: Na only adults fit get STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Anybody wey dey sexually active fit get STI, no matter age.

Pidgin.statement: If both partners be virgin, dem no fit get STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If both of una never do any sexual thing before, risk dey low.

Pidgin.statement: Vaccine dey to prevent some STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! HPV vaccine dey help protect against some cancer wey STI dey cause.

Pidgin.statement: HIV fit spread through mosquito bite.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! HIV no dey spread by mosquito — na only certain fluid fit carry am.

Pidgin.statement: STI always dey show sign like itching or discharge.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Some STI no dey show any sign. Testing dey important.

Pidgin.statement: To use two condoms at once dey protect you more.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! The friction go make dem tear. Use one well-correct condom instead.

Pidgin.statement: If person get HIV, dem fit still live long life if dem get treatment.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! With medicine, people fit live long, healthy life even with HIV.

Pidgin.statement: Na only people wey get plenty partner dey get STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Even one partner fit give you STI if dem get am.

Pidgin.statement: To baff after sex go stop belle.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Baffing no dey stop belle or STI — na condom or protection go help.

Pidgin.statement: Some STI fit cure with antibiotic.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! STI like chlamydia fit cure, but some like HIV no get cure.

Pidgin.statement: Toilet seat fit pass STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! STI no dey survive for surface like that — no dey fear toilet seat.

Pidgin.statement: If you confuse about sex, make you talk to trusted adult.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! Trusted adult go give you correct info and guide you.

Pidgin.statement: If sperm near vagina, person fit still get belle.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! Even if penis no enter fully, sperm fit still cause belle.

Pidgin.statement: Birth control pills dey protect against STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Pills dey stop belle only — dem no dey stop STI.

Pidgin.statement: People wey get STI always sabi say dem get am.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Plenty people no dey show sign. Testing na the only way to know.

Pidgin.statement: The only sure way to avoid STI and belle na to no do sex at all.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If you no do sex, you no fit get belle or catch STI.

Pidgin.statement: You fit get STI if you share drink with person.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! STI no dey pass through cups or drink — na through sex or fluid.

Pidgin.statement: To test for STI go make people think say you dey do anyhow.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! To do STI test show say you dey responsible for your health.

Pidgin.statement: Even if you no get symptom, you fit still get STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! STI fit dey body without any sign. Na why regular testing dey important.

Pidgin.statement: Once person don get STI before, dem no fit get am again.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Some STI fit come back if person expose again.

Pidgin.statement: Condom dey expire.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If condom don expire, e fit tear. Always check the expiry date.

Pidgin.statement: To urinate after sex go prevent STI.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! E fit help reduce UTI but e no go stop STI.

Pidgin.statement: HIV treatment fit make person no pass the virus give others.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If person dey take HIV meds well, dem no go fit pass am give another.

Pidgin.statement: Only gay people dey get HIV.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Anybody fit get HIV, no matter who dem dey sleep with.

Pidgin.statement: STI dey always cause pain or itching.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Many people no dey feel anything even if dem get STI.

Pidgin.statement: Condom no dey 100% perfect, but e still better than nothing.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! E no dey perfect but e reduce risk well well if you use am correct.

Pidgin.statement: If you trust your partner, you no need use condom.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Even trust no dey stop infection. Talk openly and still use protection.

Pidgin.statement: STI fit make woman no fit get belle later.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! If STI no get treatment, e fit block chance to born.

Pidgin.statement: You go always know if condom tear during sex.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Sometimes you no go know. Always check am before and after.

Pidgin.statement: Once you don get STI, nobody go want date you again.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! With treatment and honesty, healthy relationship still dey possible.

Pidgin.statement: Boys no suppose worry about get belle.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Boys suppose help prevent belle too — e concern both people.

Pidgin.statement: If you no feel sick, you no need HIV test.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! HIV fit dey body for long without sign. Test na the only way to know.

Pidgin.statement: If condom enter body, you no fit bring am out yourself.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Sometimes you fit try remove am, but if you no fit, go hospital sharp.

Pidgin.statement: To talk about sex or STI dey shameful.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! To talk about your health dey brave and smart.

Pidgin.statement: HPV dey cause genital warts and cancer.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! HPV fit cause both. HPV vaccine dey help prevent am.

Pidgin.statement: You no fit get STI if you do sex inside water.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Sex inside water no dey stop STI or belle. Still use protection.

Pidgin.statement: To check your STI status na part of good relationship.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! E show say you care for yourself and your partner.

Pidgin.statement: Once you use condom, you no need any other protection.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Condom good, but to combine with other method fit give extra safety.

Pidgin.statement: People wey no dey do sex no need learn about STI or pregnancy.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! Knowledge dey important, even if you never start sex.

Pidgin.statement: To carry condom no mean say you bad.
Pidgin.explanation: Na true! E mean say you wise and you dey take care of yourself.

Pidgin.statement: If you no talk about STI, e no go happen.
Pidgin.explanation: Na lie! To talk about am dey help you plan and protect yourself.
